results.title: Hamlet [Animated]
results.creator_credit: et al, Natalia Orlova, Elizabeth Babakhina, Christopher Grace and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: With two US Emmy Awards, “Shakespeare - Animated tales” has won a vast new audience with its skilful, 30 minute adaptations. This can be used as a companion piece to the study of “Hamlet”, however it is far too succinct a precis to be a useful study piece for serious students of the Bard.

results.title: Hamlet (Zeffirelli)
results.creator_credit: Franco Zeffirelli, Dyson Lovell, Nelson Films and World Icon
results.brief_description: On a windswept battlement looming over a stormy sea, in a stone castle guarding a northern kingdom, a man stands alone, haunted by the mysteries of fate, love, violence, tenderness, revenge. Searching for the truth behind an evil deed which left his father dead and his mother sitting on a royal throne beside the murderer. Tortured by his inability to take action. Searching for his very soul. Hamlet, Prince of Denmark. This lavish production directed by Franco Zeffirelli has assembled a cast to infuse the Shakespearian classic with a new light. Starring Mel Gibson as Hamlet opposite Glenn Close in the role of Gertrude and a supporting cast that includes, Alan Bates, Paul Scofield, Ian Holm and Helena Bonham-Carter as Ophelia.

results.title: Hamlet (Richardson)
results.creator_credit: Tony Richardson and Columbia Pictures Industries
results.brief_description: Nicol Williamson plays Hamlet and Marianne Faithfull, Ophelia, in this version directed by Tony Richardson, filmed in London’s Round House Theatre. The strong close-ups emphasises the impact of the spoken word above all else in this production. The excellent cast includes Anthony Hopkins as Claudius, Judy Parfit as Gertrude and Gordon Jackson as Horatio.

results.title: Hamlet (Olivier)
results.brief_description: Olivier’s version of Hamlet was described by him as “an essay in Hamlet”. The text has been dramatically cut, the order transposed in places, and some new implications worked into the action. Technically the film makes use of a number of camera devices, particularly the travelling camera. The characterization does not depart from the traditional.

results.title: Hamlet (Kozintsev)
results.brief_description: In the opening sequence of this production the whole line of the film is boldly laid down. Hamlet gallops across the sands towards Elsinore, and into the great sombre castle; Claudius’ rule is proclaimed in the crowded courtyard; the drawbridge is slowly pulled up, shutting the castle in on itself. Where Kozintsev scores, consistently and impressively is through the elements outlined in the film’s vigorous introduction; the way he involves the onlookers of Elsinore in the action, and the way he uses the castle and the court to create a feeling of encirclement by iron, stone and the watchful eye of the courtiers. The emphasis is on speed, clarity, the flow of visual action. It cuts a firm, slashing line through the play.

results.title: Hamersley '66
results.creator_credit: Norman Castle, Lilias Castle and Fraser Castle Productions
results.brief_description: Shows the construction of an iron ore mine at Mount Tom Price in the Hamersley Range of Western Australia. In 1962 enormous high grade ore deposits were discovered, Hamersley Iron was contracted to supply ore to Japan in 1966. The silence of the arid red land was shattered by immense pieces of machinery feverishly working to meet the deadline.

results.title: Hamburger hill
results.creator_credit: John irvin, Jim Carabatos, Marcia Nasatir, Interaccess, Nasitir-Carabatsos and RKO Radio Pictures
results.brief_description: Set during the Vietnamese conflict in 1969, “Hamburger Hill” is a realistic, horrific dramatic depiction, almost documentary-like in format, of one of the bloodiest battles of the Vietnam War. The film follows the fortunes of 14 recruits through 10 days of hell as they make repeated assaults on a heavily fortified hill. The developing relationships between the young soldiers is tested by the grim realities of war and death. “Hamburger Hill” is a moving tribute to the men who fought a futile campaign which resulted in 70% of casualties.

results.title: Hamburger
results.brief_description: Hamburger focuses on the fast food industry; providing an insight into the two largest hamburger chains in the world; MacDonalds and Burger King. These two fast food chains have made a dramatic impact, not only on the food industry itself; but on the social and economic lives of individuals. The fast food market has been revolutionised into an industrial process which has had a serious impact on the environment. A powerful documentary in two episodes: Big Mac” and “International Mincemeat.

results.title: Hamam: the Turkish bath
results.creator_credit: Ferzan Ozpetec, Maurizio Tedesco, Marco Risi and Sorpasso Film
results.brief_description: This Italian-Turkish co-production is the story of a successful Italian businessman, Francesco, who goes to Istanbul to settle the estate of his estranged Aunt. In Turkey he encounters his Aunt’s surrogate family and decides to stay on in Istanbul and restore an old hamam (Turkish bath). Francesco finds that not only is he attracted to the generosity of his new “family”, he also finds himself sexually attracted to the son, Mehmet. When his wife Marta arrives from Italy they find themselves locked in a bitter exchange that strips bare the lies and evasions that underpin their marriage. For both Marta and Francesco, the city of Istanbul - half European, half Asian - comes to symbolise a freedom, a romance and a community that is no longer available in the fast-paced materialistic culture of Western Europe. And for both of them, with the destruction of their marriage and the intervention of violent tragedy, they discover themselves recreating the Aunt’s original exile. Filmed in location in Istanbul, this is the first film of Turkish director Ferzan Ozpetac. Cast includes Allessandro Gassman and Francesca d’Aloja. In Italian and Turkish with English subtitles. (Awards: Winner of two Golden Globe Awards for Best First Film and for Best Musical Score)
